title: The 'workshop of the world' is back in business

Tue, Sep 8, 2015, 10:21 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 9 mins The 'workshop of the world' is back in business By Rebecca Burn-Callander | Telegraph – 3 hours ago 5.4142 -0.0158 
A £20m investment by the Reece Group will bring new life to historic Vickers works in Newcastle 
The Armstrong Works in Newcastle, the factory which produced the hydraulics for Tower Bridge in London and built the “bouncing bombs” used by the Dambusters, could regain its former title as the “workshop of the world” after a £20m investment by Reece Group. 
The family engineering business, founded in 1982 by Alan Reece, an entrepreneur and philanthropist, has set up shop in the vast building, which stretches the length of five football pitches beside the River Tyne. 
Set up by industrialist Lord William Armstrong 160 years ago, the Armstrong Works employed 25,000 people at its peak. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) became engineering conglomerate Vickers-Armstrongs in 1927, and simply Vickers 50 years later . 
The factory was officially reopened last week by Alan Shearer, the former Newcastle United footballer, after lying dormant for three years. In 2012, BAE Systems (LSE: BA.L - news ) , the former owner of the site, announced the closure of the factory with the loss of 330 jobs . 
Mr Reece, who died in 2012 , is succeeded by his son John, 54. He is now the same age that his father was when he started the company. 
“This was one of the earliest examples of a university spin-out; my father was an academic for most of his life,” he says. “I can’t imagine what he might have achieved if he’d started a business at 24.” 
Reece Group has a diversified business model, making medical instruments, drilling machinery for the oil and gas industry and, most notably, products for the defence industry. 
The company manufactures mine rollers, which allow tanks to survive improvised explosive device (IED) attacks and have been used by almost every Western army, as well as other equipment deployed in Iraq and Afghanistan. “We’ve saved a lot of soldiers’ lives,” says Reece. 
The company, which has a turnover of £70m, has consolidated its pothole repair firm Velocity, defence specialist Pearson Engineering and machining and fabrication business Responsive Engineering into the new site, moving 500 people. 
It aims to grow its defence arm significantly over the next two years. “We’ve just won a contract to refurbish 60 Challenger (Hamburg: 4SE.HM - news ) 2 tanks ,” says Reece. “They were originally built in this factory, so it’s like they’re coming home.” Britain’s Warrior armoured tanks are also due an overhaul. 
Reece claims that the company will take on 100 new people in the next 18 months and turnover will rise to £100m. 
Innovation is crucial to the company’s survival all the defence products are designed by Reece Group’s team of engineers and scientists. The business has now established its own Innovation Centre to generate a steady pipeline of new inventions. 
“We employ 12 people in the centre but we’re also supporting other start-ups,” says Reece. “We have one medical equipment business in there at the moment.” 
Much of the Innovation Centre’s current work centres on condition monitoring and data collection for big ultility companies, an area that Reece believes could prove lucrative in future. “It’s early days as we’ve only been going for a year,” he says. “But as a family business, it’s important that our assets are as diversified as possible.” 
Reece Group once provided a significant amount of drilling machinery to oil and gas companies but that industry went into freefall when the price of oil fell. “Many of the markets we work in are extremely volatile,” says Reece. “Everyone wants the highest quality at the lowest price, so we’re always under pressure.” 
Another challenge for the company is finding talented people. It runs its own apprenticeship programme , taking in unskilled workers and training them up over four years. 
This is extremely expensive Reece claims that only 10pc to 15pc of their working hours are actually productive during this time but is often the only way to get the right kind of technical abilities into the business. “We’re one of the bigger employers of apprentices in Newcastle. One-in-10 of our staff came through as an apprentice.” 
The family also runs a charitable trust, the Reece Foundation, which works to find and train up the next wave of British engineers. As for the future management of the company, according to Reece, there are seven members of the family in the next generation that could come into the business . “They are all either in education or getting experience in other companies,” he says. “I’m hoping that some of them will come back.” 
Reece Group is one of several companies investing heavily in the North East. Its Armstrong Works redevelopment follows the £82m Hitachi (Other OTC: HTHIF - news ) train plant in County Durham and the latest £100m investment by Nissan into its Sunderland plant. 
“At the moment, more jobs are being created in the North East at a faster rate than anywhere else in the UK and wages are going up faster,” George Osborne, the Chancellor, said last week. 
Reece is hopeful that his new factory will reach capacity within two to three years, contributing to the North East boom. “As a Geordie, I’m committed to Newcastle and the North East,” he says “Our £20m investment is a measure of that commitment.”
